transcript.text: In Japanese schools, students memorize 100+ kanji characters
in a day and we here take 3 days to memorize a formula. Today's video
is inspired by his method. You will learn the five memory systems that Japanese
students use to lock memory with visual plus logic plus emotion
. Comment. Are you a visual learner or without emotion or logic, nothing is remembered
. Let's find out your memory type and hack it
in Japanese style. First Kanji Coding. How do the Japanese use visual recall? Imagine an eight-
year-old child writing with chalk. The same character over and over again as if it is
engraving inside the brain. Japanese children memorize Kanji. Not by spelling but
by story. Every Kanji is like an image. And they connect it to real life. For example,
the Kanji of a tree is visible. Like a tree. With the pattern of branches and roots.
You can also add mini doodles or symbols with the text in your notes. The brain
processes visuals 60,000 times faster than words. Use this advantage.
Come on. Second tip: Mnemonics meets emotion. Memory with drama. Japanese memory coaches
focus on one thing over and over again. Emotion means retention. Their mnemonic system is
not boring. It is dramatic. For example, mitochondria is equal to the power house of
the cell. Imagine it as an angry energy factory that chides the chilling
cells. This is stupid, but being emotional also works. Emotions
leave a chemical trace in your brain and that trace becomes memory.
Add a little drama to the dull facts in your flash cards. Funny face, weird story or
a little exaggeration. Memory will get a turbo boost. Third, interleaved practice, mix
it up, remember better. Do you study maths even after maths? Always Physics after Physics
. Japanese students never do this. They use interleaved
practice. Topics are put in between each other. Maths, History,
Physics, back to Maths. Every time the brain switches topics, active recall kicks in
. It seems a little difficult in the beginning. But the memory goes deep. Next
time when you make a study plan, don't add the same things. Mix different subjects
as if you are giving a workout to the brain. Preparation has just begun. You
have seen only three Japanese memory systems so far. And now comes the method that
locks your revision. Like password protected memory. Comment if you have learned anything new.
Brain power unlocked. And don't forget to like the video. This brain workout
is available for free. Fourth, teaching as recall. Why do Japanese students
explain walls? I once saw a Japanese exchange student. He
was talking to a wall outside the classroom. At first I thought he was crazy but he was using the Fine
Man Technique. Whatever topic he read, he would explain it in his own words. As if he
was explaining it to a 5 year old child. This technique
is popular in Japan's regular schools. Teach to lock in. When you explain, you catch the gaps. Try it.
Record a voice note of what you read in the morning and explain it in the evening. Fifth space not spaced.
Power of visual gaps. Space repetition is not the only important thing in studies.
Sometimes space also becomes the biggest memory hack. Japanese notebooks use
massive white space. Where we have a lot of notes written. There
is breathing room around every point on their pages. Why? Because when the brain has
visual gaps, it automatically organizes and recalls better. Next
time when you make notes, keep the white space intentional. Take a break between every major idea
for visual rhythm. So now you have the five Japanese memory secrets, visual
recall like kanji, emotional mnemonics, topic mixing, fine man style
explanation and visual wide space. To remember, you need rhythm, not rote learning.
Subscribe to Gyani Stick where studying is not a science but an art and you
are a student of that art.
